comments:
This course was about the foundations of contemporary social science. It focused on the nature of social systems, the similarities and differences between social and natural sciences, the construction, analysis, and confirmation of social theories, and the nature of social explanations. Students were expected to construct and analyze simple computational models of social phenomena. Prerequisites for this class includes PHIL 008 or PPE 008, ECON 001, and one other social science course.

Students found the course material to be “relevant for a PPE major.” While the subject material was very dense, the lectures were “informative, yet fast-paced.” Students showed some concern about the grading system of the course. Many students found that the format of the test failed to display their understanding of the material. Although students thought grading was “sometimes subjective,” they were not given “feedback or opportunities to improve.”

Professor Weisberg, according to students, is “very passionate and does an excellent job conveying the material.” He was very engaging in lectures, and “available for help outside of the classroom.

Students stated that the course “requires a real commitment from the student.” There were a lot of dense assigned readings, and some found them to be irrelevant to the course material sometimes. “Because students are held to a very high standard in class evaluation,” students did not recommend this class to non-major students.
